ygData.subject: New Multiagent HyperNEAT Journal Paper
ygData.msgSnippet: David D Ambrosio and I are pleased to announce a new comprehensive journal paper on multiagent HyperNEAT, Scalable Multiagent Learning through Indirect

Subject: New Multiagent HyperNEAT Journal Paper
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=XkxdqUUvmWfgthtxtPFyQeJkgJiVvmElce5dEODuvGcfvD6X3CkA

David D'Ambrosio and I are pleased to announce a new comprehensive journal =
paper on multiagent HyperNEAT, "Scalable Multiagent Learning through Indire=
ct Encoding of Policy Geometry,"  which is appearing in Evolutionary Intell=
igence journal:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2013/dambrosio-evin13=


Videos: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/demos/multiagentcompared

The main idea i=
n multiagent HyperNEAT, which has appeared already in a number of conferenc=
e publications, is to take advantage of HyperNEAT's ability to encode geome=
tric patterns of weights to evolve genomes that encode an entire team of ne=
ural networks.  That way, in effect it learns a pattern of roles (which we =
called the "policy geometry") across the agents of the team.  

In this pap=
er we highlight the benefits of this kind of multiagent learning by compari=
ng to a multiagent reinforcement learning (MARL) approach called multiagent=
 SARSA, yielding the first such comparison of its kind.  While multiagent S=
ARSA does well at training small teams, the larger the teams become, the le=
ss SARSA can succeed.  In contrast, multiagent HyperNEAT does something int=
eresting as team size increases:  It fundamentally reorganizes its team-wid=
e strategies into more complex and effective divide-and-conquer strategies =
that take into account the holistic cooperation of the team.

Best,

ken
